awd_titl_txt: The Effect of Particle Phase State on Multiphase Hydroxyl Radical (OH) Oxidation Kinetics and Products of Biomass Burning Aerosol
awd_abstract_narration:
Biomass burning aerosols (BBA) are ubiquitous throughout the global atmosphere. BBA source strength is believed to be of similar magnitude to the fossil fuel burning aerosols. Biomass burning plumes can affect the atmosphere on local to global scales, and BBAs can have a significant impact on visibility, and on the radiative forcing due to the direct scattering and absorption of radiation. By altering the properties of clouds, BBA also exert indirect effects on the radiation balance. Organic aerosols, representing a major mass fraction of the submicron size fraction, are implicated in human health effects. During atmospheric transport, organic aerosol particles are chemically transformed due to reactions with trace oxidizing species such as the hydroxyl radical (OH), resulting in chemical aging and ultimately cleansing of the atmosphere.  

The chemical aging of BBA particles by reactive trace gas species is not well understood, and so far investigations have been limited mostly to room temperature and dry conditions, although most of the atmosphere exhibits oxidizing conditions at lower temperatures and wider variations in relative humidity.  Ambient environmental parameters,  which induce altered viscosity or even phase changes,  are responsible for altered chemical reactivity in BBA, and may in turn be responsible for altering the kinetics of many of these chemical transformations.  

A series of laboratory based investigations, using proxy and surrogate compounds under controlled conditions, are to be carried out in order to further describe the chemical transformations taking place during the formation, dispersal and aging of natural, biomass burning aerosols

por.por_cntn:
Biomass burning as a result of, e.g., forest fires and residential heating and cooking, releases a large amount of gases and particles comparable to emissions from burning of fossil fuel. The particulate matter stemming from such burns is mostly organic in nature. These organic aerosol (OA) particles can consist of multiple compounds and exert various phase states. It has been recognized that OA particles can be amorphous in nature, i.e., the organic particle compounds can transition continuously between the liquid, semisolid, and solid states. This is in contrast, e.g., the melting of ice that occurs at a fixed temperature of 0 C. The phase state of these OA particles will change in response to ambient temperature and humidity, where higher temperature and humidity leads to a more liquid-like phase and vice versa. Biomass burning plumes from strong wildfires can reach the stratosphere and travel the globe within days to weeks. During this atmospheric transport, these OA particles react with atmospheric oxidants leading to the chemical transformation of the particles with important implications for air quality and climate. Temperatures in the troposphere can reach as low as -70 C which, in turn, will modulate the phase state of the OA particles. It is not well-understood how these phase transitions impact the reactivity towards atmospheric oxidants which is crucial information to improve our predictive capability of the chemical evolution of the atmospheric OA population. To advance our understanding in this matter, we examined the reactivity between typical OA surrogates and atmospheric oxidants as the organic compounds change their phase state in response to changes in the ambient temperature.

Intellectual Merit: We conducted laboratory experiments that improve our understanding of how particle phase state modulated by temperature and humidity impacts the oxidation reactions between typical organic surrogates representing biomass burning aerosol (BBA) and gaseous oxidants such as ozone (O3), nitrate radical (NO3), and hydroxyl radical (OH). We developed a new experimental setup that allowed us to determine the reaction kinetics between O3, NO3 and OH and amorphous OA surrogates for temperatures between -60 C and 40 C. To evaluate the phase state of the organic matter we built a poke-flow experiment yielding viscosity information for examined temperature ranges. Our study demonstrates unambiguously that the chemical reactivity of organic matter towards atmospheric oxidants can vary significantly in response to changes in ambient temperature that modulates the organic phase state. The greatest differences in reactivity occur in the temperature range where the organic compound transitions from a solid to a liquid state. At colder temperatures where the organic compound is in a solid state, the reactivity is significantly lower compared to when the compound is in a liquid or semisolid state. These results imply that OA particles, such as the ones emitted during biomass burning, during transport in the free troposphere have significantly longer lifetimes with respect to chemical degradation. These findings can explain the presence of OA particles in the higher altitudes of the atmosphere and the long-range transport of wildfire smoke. Our experimental data represent important information for our understanding of the chemical evolution of OA particles and their impact on source apportionment, air quality, and climate.

Broader Impacts: This award provided research opportunities for 2 graduate students (1 female) allowing to continue and finish their Ph.D. studies and the writing of peer-reviewed journal articles. This award focused on increasing the number of underrepresented minority students in the atmospheric sciences. We contributed atmospheric chemistry projects to the university Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) program. 8 female students took part in these activities. We also furthered the exposure of underrepresented minority students to atmospheric sciences by participation in a CSTEP (Collegiate Science and Technology Entry Program) summer residential program at Stony Brook University for underrepresented minority students from high-needs school districts. We offered an atmospheric science module for the CSTEP summer program to raise the interest of advanced middle and high school students from local high-needs school districts for atmospheric chemistry and awareness of local pollution problems such as high ozone concentration during summer over Long Island, NY. About 70 high school students participated in this program over the award period. Scientific advances have been disseminated to the broader research community through 5 published peer-reviewed journal articles, 1 peer-reviewed journal article currently in review, 2 manuscripts in preparation, 2 Ph.D. thesis (currently being written), 2 invited symposia presentations, 12 conference proceedings, and 7 seminar presentations.
